block.p: Taiwan Leader Extends Invitation to Beijing Taiwan's new president, Chen Shui-bian, left, emboldened by the warm summit meeting between the leaders of North and South Korea, invited his Chinese counterpart, Jiang Zemin, to join him in a similar effort.

Strategy on China Trade Bill President Clinton summoned a bipartisan group of senators to discuss how to pass the China trade bill.

Putting Off Antimissile Decision The Clinton administration is maneuvering to sidestep a decision over whether to build a national missile defense system, playing down the significance of the Pentagon's next test of the system and leaving final decisions on deployment to the next administration, officials said.

W.H.O. Ranks Health Systems A World Health Organization report indicated that European health systems generally performed best and that the United States was lagging, largely because of unequal distribution of health care services.
Brazil Acts to Curb Crime Brazil decreed an immediate ban on the sale of firearms as part of a broader ''national security plan'' intended to reduce urban violence.

Inquiry Into Migrants' Deaths British officials investigating the deaths of 58 Chinese immigrants found in a freight container ordered the driver held on suspicion of manslaughter and began interviewing two men who had survived.
Prize Stirs German Controversy The awarding of a prestigious literary prizes to Ernst Nolte, a historian who has sought to justify the Holocaust, has ignited a fierce dispute.
Israel Party Quits Coalition The Shas party quit Prime Minister Ehud Barak's governing coalition. But the move does not take effect for 48 hours, leaving time to bargain.

Senate Votes to Include Gays in Hate-Crime Law The Senate, in a bipartisan 57-to-42 vote, approved legislation to make hate attacks on gays a federal crime. The Senate passed a similar measure last year, quietly and by unanimous consent, only to see it killed in a House-Senate conference, and Republican leaders said they planned to do so again.

Higher Medicare Payment Urged President Clinton proposed increasing Medicare payments to hospitals, nursing homes and other health care providers, as evidence grew that cuts made in 1997 had harmed the quality of care in the country.

Gore Retirement Savings Plan Vice President Al Gore offered his plan for government-subsidized savings accounts, saying they would help families build wealth for retirement and other uses without putting guaranteed Social Security benefits at risk in the stock market.
Bush Plan for Math and Science Gov. George W. Bush proposed spending an additional $2.3 billion over five years in federal funds to improve math and science education in public schools.
Indiana Suspends Gas Tax Gov. Frank L. O'Bannon suspended the state's gas tax and warned that he might seek an inquiry into possible oil company price gouging.
Waco Suit Goes to Trial Opening statements were made in the civil suit against the government by survivors and relatives of those killed in the 1993 fire at the Branch Davidian compound.
Mob Violence in Los Angeles Roving mobs that grew to several thousand people attacked police cars and other vehicles and vandalized businesses after the Lakers' victory in the N.B.A. championship.
Trend to Older Motherhood Public health officials confirmed that in 1998 Massachusetts became the first state in which more babies were born to women over the age of 30 than under it.

80 Injured as Subway Train Derails in Brooklyn At least 80 people were injured, three of them critically, when a subway train derailed as it pulled out of the DeKalb Avenue station in downtown Brooklyn. Mayor Giuliani said that transit officials hoped to have trains running normally by this morning's rush hour.

Skakel Confession Alleged Two witnesses told a judge in Stamford, Conn., that Michael C. Skakel, a nephew of Ethel Kennedy, had confessed to killing Martha Moxley, 15, in 1975. They said he made the statements in the late 1970's while in a school for troubled youths. The judge is to decide whether Mr. Skakel, 39, should be tried as a juvenile or an adult.

Plan for Disabled Students The New York City Board of Education is expected to approve a plan today that would move thousands of students classified as disabled into regular classrooms during the next three to five years.

Rumblings of an Umpire Strike John Hirschbeck, the president of the umpires' new union, said in an interview that he was ''very disappointed in baseball'' and that umpires had discussed among themselves the possibility of a strike, though there are no plans to take a strike vote.

A Reprieve for Microsoft The trial judge in the Microsoft antitrust case issued an order delaying the sweeping restrictions on company conduct that he imposed on June 7, pending a higher court's decision on the restrictions.
Mutual Fund Combination Alliance Capital Management agreed to acquire the privately held money management and research firm Sanford C. Bernstein & Company for $3.5 billion.

Fraud Charge for Shoe Designer Steven Madden, chairman and chief executive of the Steven Madden women's shoe company, was arrested on federal charges of securities fraud that included the initial public offering of his own company, in 1993.
Slight Rise in Oil Output Seen OPEC ministers meeting today in Vienna are expected to agree on a modest production increase, but the move is unlikely to bring much relief to American consumers.
